Suppose we're in a 2-category CCC and we're studying the limit of a diagram shaped like this:

x1←x2←x3←⋯ x_1 \leftarrow x_2 \leftarrow x_3 \leftarrow \cdots x1​←x2​←x3​←⋯

Suppose this diagram has a strict 2-limit, i.e. this diagram has a limit in the underlying 1-category of CCC. Is this strict limit also necessarily the limit in the 2-categorical sense?
(There is some information about related topics at [[semiflexible limit]], but I'm unable to use it to answer my question.)
I guess you mean the up-to-isomorphism 2-categorical sense, a.k.a. the bilimit.
(By the way, a strict 2-limit is a bit more than a limit in the underlying 1-category: it also says says something about 2-cells into the limit corresponding to 2-cells between cones.)

I'm not sure I know the answer to that. I'm pretty sure sequential limits aren't PIE-limits, but I don't know whether they're flexible or semiflexible. I would guess not, but I don't have a counterexample right away.

I think if you take a sequence of groups not satisfying the Mittag-Leffler condition, so that it has a nontrivial derived limit, then the naive limit is homotopically wrong. Let me try to see if I can make this more elementary and clear.

Hmm...I know that the sequence ...→Z→Z...\to \mathbb Z\to \mathbb Z...→Z→Z where all the maps are multiplication by 222 is supposed to have nontrivial lim⁡1\lim^1lim1, and that ought to mean that the bilimit of either this diagram (of discrete groupoids) or its delooping is not the same as the strict limit, but I haven't been able to show this directly yet.
I think it must be the delooping.
Right, that's where I was working too, I guess the discrete groupoid diagram has 2-limit and bilimit both empty.
Or maybe {0}\{0\}{0}?

Let's see, the Milnor exact sequence says that given a tower of fibrations of spaces ⋯→X2→X1→X0\cdots \to X_2 \to X_1\to X_0⋯→X2​→X1​→X0​, for each q∈Nq\in \mathbb{N}q∈N there is a short exact sequence

0→lim⁡1πq+1(Xi)→πq(lim⁡Xi)→lim⁡πq(Xi)→00 \to \lim{}^1 \pi_{q+1}(X_i) \to \pi_q(\lim X_i) \to \lim \pi_q(X_i) \to 00→lim1πq+1​(Xi​)→πq​(limXi​)→limπq​(Xi​)→0

So if we convert your delooped sequence ⋯→BZ→BZ→BZ\cdots \to B\mathbb{Z}\to B\mathbb{Z}\to B\mathbb{Z}⋯→BZ→BZ→BZ to a tower of fibrations, which doesn't change the homotopy groups, then the strict limit of the fibrations will be the homotopy limit of the original delooped tower. Taking q=0q=0q=0, then each π0(Xi)=0\pi_0(X_i) = 0π0​(Xi​)=0, so the right-hand object is trivial. But the sequence π1(Xi)\pi_1(X_i)π1​(Xi​) on the left will be the sequence of groups ⋯→Z→Z→Z\cdots \to \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}⋯→Z→Z→Z, which has nontrivial lim⁡1\lim{}^1lim1, and thus the middle object π0(lim⁡Xi)\pi_0(\lim X_i)π0​(limXi​) will be nontrivial, i.e. the homotopy limit of the original delooped tower is disconnected. But certainly the strict limit of the original tower is connected (and, I think, even trivial).

Mike Shulman said:

Or maybe {0}\{0\}{0}?

Oh yeah, yeah.

And yeah, that argument looks right; I wasn't tracking the interaction between fibrant replacement and homotopy/strict limits. I agree the original tower has a point as its strict limit, i.e. a single object with endomorphisms given by all the elements of Z\mathbb ZZ that are infinitely divisible by 2.2.2.

To make this a full answer to John's question we just need to remember how homotopy limits of groupoids are related to bilimits of the (2,1)(2,1)(2,1)-category; they're the same since groupoids are reflective in spaces (say in terms of ∞\infty∞-categories.)

Thanks so much, guys! So you're looking at the strict versus the homotopy limit of the sequence of groupoids

BZ←BZ←⋯ B \mathbb{Z} \leftarrow B \mathbb{Z} \leftarrow \cdots BZ←BZ←⋯

where each arrow comes from Z←2×−Z \mathbb{Z} \xleftarrow{2 \times -} \mathbb{Z}Z2×−​Z. And you're saying the strict limit is the terminal groupoid, while the homotopy limit is not.

Now I'm really curious what the homotopy limit is, spelled out in the language of groupoids!
Somehow my understanding of homological algebra never penetrated to lim⁡1\lim^1lim1. :crying_cat:

For some reason @Todd Trimble and @Joe Moeller and I are dealing with a diagram of Vect-enriched categories

C1←C2←⋯ C_1 \leftarrow C_2 \leftarrow \cdots C1​←C2​←⋯

where I feel in my bones that the strict limit is the bilimit. Let me say what it is.

CkC_kCk​ is the category of Nk\mathbb{N}^kNk-graded vector spaces of finite total dimension, i.e. the sums of the dimensions of the grades is finite. This is a full subcategory of FinVectNk\mathsf{FinVect}^{\mathbb{N}^k}FinVectNk.

The functor Ck←Ck+1C_k \leftarrow C_{k+1}Ck​←Ck+1​ is induced by the inclusion Nk→Nk+1\mathbb{N}^k \to \mathbb{N}^{k+1}Nk→Nk+1 sending (n1,…,nk)(n_1, \dots, n_k) (n1​,…,nk​) to (n1,…,nk,0)(n_1, \dots, n_k, 0)(n1​,…,nk​,0).

I guess my problem is that I don't know a good way to compute the bilimit of a big long diagram of Vect-enriched categories like

C1←C2←⋯ C_1 \leftarrow C_2 \leftarrow \cdots C1​←C2​←⋯

even if I have a very good understanding of that diagram.
We understand the strict limit quite well; I won't bore you by explaining it.

The big difference between this situation and your counterexample might be that my arrows Ck←Ck+1C_k \leftarrow C_{k+1}Ck​←Ck+1​ are 'surjective' - more precisely, they are essentially surjective and full functors.
Are they "fibrations"? The strict limit of a tower of fibrations is generally equivalent to its homotopy limit, as long as there's a suitable model-category-like-thing around.
Okay, good! They feel like fibrations to me. So I guess I should look for some model structure on the category of Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect-enriched categories where they actually are.
You could try Lack's model structure that exists on any 2-category with enough limits and colimits.
Where can I read about that? In the case of Cat, is this model structure the [[canonical model structure on Cat]]?
Homotopy-theoretic aspects of 2-monads, and yes.

Interestingly, although the notion of "2-category with enough limits and colimits" is self-dual, Lack's construction is not. So actually any 2-category with enough limits and colimits has two canonical model structures. In the case of Cat, they happen to coincide.
Thanks!

For taking limits, wouldn't it be fine to just look at these as categories rather than Vect\mathbf{Vect}Vect-enriched categories? Then the fibrations are just isofibrations, which these functors Ck←Ck+1C_k\leftarrow C_{k+1}Ck​←Ck+1​ are.

And I believe a morphism (an)→(bn)(a_n)\to (b_n)(an​)→(bn​) is another sequence (αn)(\alpha_n)(αn​) such that an+αn=bn+2αn+1.a_n+\alpha_n=b_n+2\alpha_{n+1}.an​+αn​=bn​+2αn+1​. In particular, if an=bna_n=b_nan​=bn​ then the only morphism is 0,0,0, so that XXX has trivial fundamental groups at every basepoint. The non-integer-valued sequence (−23,−43,−83,…),(-\frac 23,-\frac 43,-\frac 83,\ldots),(−32​,−34​,−38​,…), is one solution and the kernel of the linear operator sending αn↦αn−2αn+1\alpha_n\mapsto \alpha_n-2\alpha_{n+1}αn​↦αn​−2αn+1​ is (a0,a02,a04,…),(a_0,\frac{a_0}2,\frac{a_0}4,\ldots),(a0​,2a0​​,4a0​​,…), so we'd need to find a0∈Qa_0\in\mathbb Qa0​∈Q such that a02n−23⋅2n\frac{a_0}{2^n}-\frac 23 \cdot 2^n2na0​​−32​⋅2n is in Z\mathbb ZZ for every n,n,n, or better yet, a0′∈Za_0'\in \mathbb Za0′​∈Z such that a0′−22n+1a_0'-2^{2n+1}a0′​−22n+1 is a multiple of 3⋅2n3\cdot 2^n3⋅2n for every n.n.n. But that says in particular that a0′−22n+1a_0'-2^{2n+1}a0′​−22n+1 is 2-adic Cauchy sequence, which rules out any option but a0′=0,a_0'=0,a0′​=0, which is not a solution.

So if I've got that right, the connected components of XXX should be in some sense classes of different possible 2-adic behaviors of integer sequences, and probably that would bring us back around to lim⁡1\lim^1lim1 if we would recall how to compute that.

You can give an injective resolution of our sequence S1S_1S1​ pretty easily like so:
Screenshot-2024-09-22-at-3.34.08PM.png
The lim⁡1\lim^1lim1 is then the cokernel of lim⁡(S2)→lim⁡(S3),\lim(S_2)\to \lim(S_3),lim(S2​)→lim(S3​), which I claim is the canonical map Q→Q/Z⊕(Z/2Z)N,\mathbb Q\to \mathbb Q/\mathbb Z\oplus (\mathbb Z/2\mathbb Z)^\mathbb N,Q→Q/Z⊕(Z/2Z)N, i.e. the standard abelian group structure on the Cantor set (Z/2Z)N(\mathbb Z/2\mathbb Z)^\mathbb N(Z/2Z)N. I'm not sure how enlightening this is but it's fun and creepy to observe that our space XXX has a profinite set of components, which wasn't obvious off the bat.
I mean, I guess XXX is just the Cantor space, up to homotopy, probably.

Kevin Carlson said:

For taking limits, wouldn't it be fine to just look at these as categories rather than Vect\mathbf{Vect}Vect-enriched categories? Then the fibrations are just isofibrations, which these functors Ck←Ck+1C_k\leftarrow C_{k+1}Ck​←Ck+1​ are.

That sounds right, which is good. I just happen to be working in the 2-category of linear categories, so I want to make sure I'm taking the limit and bilimit in there.

But actually, I'm really working in the 2-category of N\mathbb{N}N-graded Cauchy complete linear categories.

(There comes a time when someone asking for help starts providing too much detail about what they're actually doing, and now is that time. You've done enough for me, now I'm just nattering.)

Alas, this 'N\mathbb{N}N-grading' business. which I'd suppressed earlier in this conversation, actually makes a big difference. For example, to give a decategorified analogue, suppose RnR_nRn​ was the free graded ring on generators of grades 2,4,6,…,2n2, 4, 6, \dots, 2n2,4,6,…,2n. There are obvious maps Rn←Rn+1R_n \leftarrow R_{n+1}Rn​←Rn+1​ that kill off the generator of highest degree. The limit of the resulting diagram of rings is a lot bigger than the limit of the resulting diagram diagram of graded rings. This example actually shows up if you're studying the cohomology ring of CP∞\mathbb{C}\mathrm{P}^\inftyCP∞ as a limit of the cohomology rings of CPn\mathbb{C}\mathrm{P}^nCPn's. We're doing something similar but categorified.

The fibrations in Lack's model structure are the representable isofibrations. I wouldn't be surprised if in V- CatV\text{- Cat}V- Cat those are just the VVV-functors whose underlying ordinary functor is an isofibration, for any VVV.
Actually I think maybe I would be surprised if they weren't that.
